title: Ticket #7715: sub.queue_with_itemdata should verify consistency of itemdata keys
description:
When using queue_with_itemdata() where the itemdata is a sequence of dictionaries, the behavior is unexpected if the dictionaries do not all have the same keys. This example, where Requirements is not in the first dictionary, but was in the second one, illustrates the problem.

When using queue_with_itemdata() and editing "Requirements", the behavior is different when the match occurs for the first job in the list or later with the python bindings. On top of it, none of the results are the default behavior.

Example: The following submission: 

import classad
import htcondor

sub = htcondor.Submit("""
	universe = vanilla
	executable = test.sh
	arguments = 3
        Output = out.$(Cluster)-$(Process)
        Log = log.$(Cluster)
	""")

schedd = htcondor.Schedd()
jobAds = []

reqStr = ('(REQUIRED_OS=?="any")')

jobList = ["Job1", "Job2", "Job3"]
for job in jobList:
    ad = {}
    ad['RequestDisk'] = str('100025')
    ad['My.JobName'] = classad.quote(job)
    ad['My.JobNumber'] = '4'
    if "Job1" in job:
        print("Found match for Job condition")
        ad['Requirements'] = str(reqStr)

    jobAds.append(ad)

with schedd.transaction() as txn:
    submitRes = sub.queue_with_itemdata(txn, 1, iter(jobAds))
    print("ClusterId: {}".format(submitRes.cluster()))

Will produce the following result: 

$ condor_q 306399 -af:hr Requirements JobName
Requirements                                                                                                                                                                                                                              JobName
((REQUIRED_OS =?= "any")) && (TARGET.Arch == "X86_64") && (TARGET.OpSys == "LINUX") && (TARGET.Disk >= RequestDisk) && (TARGET.Memory >= RequestMemory) && ((TARGET.FileSystemDomain == MY.FileSystemDomain) || (TARGET.HasFileTransfer)) "Job1"
((REQUIRED_OS =?= "any")) && (TARGET.Arch == "X86_64") && (TARGET.OpSys == "LINUX") && (TARGET.Disk >= RequestDisk) && (TARGET.Memory >= RequestMemory) && ((TARGET.FileSystemDomain == MY.FileSystemDomain) || (TARGET.HasFileTransfer)) "Job2"
((REQUIRED_OS =?= "any")) && (TARGET.Arch == "X86_64") && (TARGET.OpSys == "LINUX") && (TARGET.Disk >= RequestDisk) && (TARGET.Memory >= RequestMemory) && ((TARGET.FileSystemDomain == MY.FileSystemDomain) || (TARGET.HasFileTransfer)) "Job3"

But if we change the following line: 

if "Job1" in job:"
with: 
if "Job2" in job:"

Then, it ignored the requirements change: 

$ condor_q 306401 -af:hr Requirements JobName
Requirements                                                                                                                                                                                                 JobName
(TARGET.Arch == "X86_64") && (TARGET.OpSys == "LINUX") && (TARGET.Disk >= RequestDisk) && (TARGET.Memory >= RequestMemory) && ((TARGET.FileSystemDomain == MY.FileSystemDomain) || (TARGET.HasFileTransfer)) "Job1"
(TARGET.Arch == "X86_64") && (TARGET.OpSys == "LINUX") && (TARGET.Disk >= RequestDisk) && (TARGET.Memory >= RequestMemory) && ((TARGET.FileSystemDomain == MY.FileSystemDomain) || (TARGET.HasFileTransfer)) "Job2"
(TARGET.Arch == "X86_64") && (TARGET.OpSys == "LINUX") && (TARGET.Disk >= RequestDisk) && (TARGET.Memory >= RequestMemory) && ((TARGET.FileSystemDomain == MY.FileSystemDomain) || (TARGET.HasFileTransfer)) "Job3"

Expected behavior: What I would expect, is that, if I plan to modify ad['Requirements'] for "Job1" only, then the results should look like: 

$ condor_q 306401 -af:hr Requirements JobName
Requirements                                                                                                                                                                                                 JobName
((REQUIRED_OS =?= "any")) && (TARGET.Arch == "X86_64") && (TARGET.OpSys == "LINUX") && (TARGET.Disk >= RequestDisk) && (TARGET.Memory >= RequestMemory) && ((TARGET.FileSystemDomain == MY.FileSystemDomain) || (TARGET.HasFileTransfer)) "Job1"
(TARGET.Arch == "X86_64") && (TARGET.OpSys == "LINUX") && (TARGET.Disk >= RequestDisk) && (TARGET.Memory >= RequestMemory) && ((TARGET.FileSystemDomain == MY.FileSystemDomain) || (TARGET.HasFileTransfer)) "Job2"
(TARGET.Arch == "X86_64") && (TARGET.OpSys == "LINUX") && (TARGET.Disk >= RequestDisk) && (TARGET.Memory >= RequestMemory) && ((TARGET.FileSystemDomain == MY.FileSystemDomain) || (TARGET.HasFileTransfer)) "Job3"

Is there a way to properly modify 'Requirements'?

2020-Jun-29 13:12:55 by karpel:
Capturing some discussion we had about this on Slack. TJ, please follow up if I got any of this wrong.

The result you get here is a consequence of how dictionary-style itemdata works. When submit sees an "extra" key (i.e., one that wasn't in the first itemdatum), it ignores it. When it sees a "missing" key (i.e., this itemdatum doesn't have a key that the first one did), it uses the most recent value for that key. Itemdata fundamentally forms a table, not a flexible schema. Each row of the table inherits the previous row's values.

This is submit's normal behavior, but you can't access it using the CLI condor_submit tool because of how you specify itemdata. This behavior is only visible when using dictionary-style itemdata through the Python bindings.

My preference would be that we raise an exception (probably ValueError) in both of the above cases (missing and extra keys). TJ prefers that we document the existing behavior, but don't raise any exceptions.

Kenyi: in this case, the way to move forward is to make sure that you set requirements explicitly in every itemdatum.
